summary: This is an FBI FD-302 form documenting an amended inventory of two suitcases seized from 9 East 71st Street on July 11, 2019. The inventory details a large amount of cash, diamonds, jewelry, watches, passports, and electronic media found in the suitcases, including an Austrian passport in a false name with Jeffrey Epstein's photograph.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Individual who provided suitcases to FBI
persons.context: Provided two suitcases to Special Agent on July 11, 2019, during the execution of a search warrant at 9 East 71st Street.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named on five expired U.S. passports found in a suitcase. His photograph was found in an Austrian passport issued under a different name.

persons.name: Marius Robert Fortelni
persons.context: Name listed on an Austrian passport that contained a photograph of Jeffrey Epstein, found in the blue suitcase.

connections.description: Kahn provided suitcases from Epstein's residence (9 East 71st Street) to the FBI during a search warrant execution, suggesting a connection to Epstein's property or affairs.

events.title: Search Warrant Execution at 9 East 71st Street
events.description: FBI executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, during which two suitcases were received from Richard Kahn.

events.title: Amended Inventory of Seized Suitcases
events.description: FBI Special Agents completed a thorough review and amended the inventory of items found in two suitcases seized from Epstein's residence.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, New York, New York, United States
keyFacts: An Austrian passport in the name of 'Marius Robert Fortelni' was found containing a photograph of Jeffrey Epstein, indicating possession of a fraudulent identity document.
The suitcases contained significant valuables including loose diamonds (48 total), over $70,000 in various currencies, expensive watches (Richard Mille, F.P. Journe), and two black hard drives.
Five expired U.S. passports in Jeffrey Epstein's name were found in the blue suitcase.
The inventory included a U.S. Department of Treasury Customs badge and an AT&T corporate card in the name 'Wexner Investment Co'.
The document corrects initial inventory errors, showing careful evidence handling and the discovery of the fraudulent passport.
